awd_titl_txt: Development of New Strategies for the Synthesis of Bacterial Carbohydrates
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Division of Chemistry is supporting Professor Weiping Tang of the Pharmaceutical Sciences Division of the University of Wisconsin-Madison to develop a systematic way to make bacterial carbohydrates from common precursors. Carbohydrates play important roles in inflammation, infection, cancer metastasis, and many other fundamentally important biological processes. The development of efficient methods to synthesize bacterial carbohydrates from simple, common starting materials is of value for the study of biological processes that involve these compounds. Unfortunately, bacteria use several hundred building blocks for carbohydrate synthesis that are not readily available; this is in contrast to humans and other mammals that use fewer than a dozen such building blocks. Bacterial carbohydrates need to be individually synthesized and then linked into oligomers, which is a time-consuming and technically challenging process. Professor Tang and his research team are developing synthetic strategies to address this roadblock and streamline the process for making these important compounds. These studies are also providing scientific training to graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, as well as younger generations of students traditionally underrepresented in STEM disciplines. Professor Tang actively participates in several collaborations where undergraduate and high school students partake in academic research and develop a lifelong appreciation for science. 

The Tang Research group is developing de novo synthesis strategies to systematically prepare a variety of bacterial carbohydrates with a high degree of stereocontrol over the glycosidic bond. In one focus area, a transition metal-catalyzed C-H amination approach is being optimized for the synthesis aminosugars and their derivatives. Simultaneously, this investigation is also providing insight in how to use C-H amination reactions in complex settings. In a second focus area, stereoselective reduction of enones followed by olefin functionalization is providing a route to rare deoxy sugars. These studies are simultaneously advancing glycoscience and synthetic organic chemistry while facilitating the study of important biological processes in bacteria. The program is also impacting chemical education at multiple levels: graduate students area gaining synthetic expertise and participating in mentoring activities that prepare them for leading positions in industry and academia, and underrepresented undergraduate and high school students and gaining hands-on experience and exposure to cutting-edge research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

During the funding period of this NSF grant, we developed a novel chemical process to create bacterial carbohydrates—molecules that are essential for studying fundamental biological processes and developing the next generation of medicines. Our method uses a combination of ruthenium, a type of metal catalyst, and boron to selectively transform specific parts of sugar molecules, called 1,2-trans-diols, into 1,2-cis-diols. This transformation is crucial for producing the building blocks of many bacterial carbohydrates, which are used in research and could lead to new treatments or vaccines in the future.

Existing methods to create bacterial carbohydrates often require many steps and are limited in the types of molecules they can produce. In contrast, our approach offers a faster, more efficient, and versatile way to synthesize these important sugars starting from readily available, common sugars. After testing a variety of ruthenium catalysts, we identified several that effectively drive the transformation of trans-diols to cis-diols. This reaction works because the boron promotes the formation of boronate esters, which shift the chemical balance toward the desired cis-diol products. These products can then be directly used for further chemical modifications, such as attaching other functional groups or building more complex sugar chains.

Using this method, we successfully synthesized a series of bacterial sugars. Remarkably, the method also works on disaccharides, demonstrating its broader applicability. Our technique consistently targets specific parts of the sugar molecules for modification, making it highly selective and reliable. We demonstrated the utility of this process by efficiently constructing key sugar structures found in natural products and bioactive compounds.

In addition to developing this method, we conducted experiments to better understand the mechanism. Our findings confirmed that the ruthenium catalyst first created a balance between the trans- and cis-diol forms, and then boron stabilized the cis form by forming boronate esters. This deeper understanding not only validates our approach but also opens up possibilities for expanding the method to create other types of bacterial sugars.

Beyond the above work, we also explored other strategies for synthesizing bacterial carbohydrates, including C-H aminations and alkene functionalizations. These approaches have helped us better understand the strengths and limitations of various techniques for carbohydrate synthesis. These insights will guide future research and are expected to lead to additional publications.

Overall, our studies represent a significant advancement in the field of carbohydrate chemistry. They not only enhance the efficiency and versatility of creating these critical molecules but also open new avenues for discoveries and applications, including the development of novel treatments, vaccines, and bioactive compounds. This work underscores the transformative potential of innovative chemical strategies to generate molecules that can deepen our understanding of complex biological processes and drive the development of the next generation of medicines.

Broader Impacts:

This NSF grant partially supported six graduate students, five postdoctoral fellows, and three undergraduate students. The NSF-funded projects provided these researchers with essential opportunities to acquire and refine critical research skills. This support contributed significantly to the professional development of the postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduate students involved.

Additionally, graduate students supported by the NSF grant participated in various outreach activities. These included a virtual Merit Badge workshop for high school students from Wisconsin, a problem-based learning lab at Madison Technical College (MTC) for undergraduate students in the Biotech Training Program, the UW Science Expeditions symposium for elementary to high school students and their families from the Madison area, and a senior-level seminar course at UW-Madison focused on the theme of "Sugar in Disease" for biochemistry students.

One publication resulted from this NSF-funded project during the grant period. The research, including the development of a new method and the characterization of novel compounds, was published in the Journal of the American Chemical Society, a highly regarded journal widely read by scientists in the field. The findings are also available in prominent databases such as SciFinder, Web of Science, PubChem, and PubMed, ensuring broad dissemination and accessibility to the scientific community.

In summary, this NSF grant supported the training of researchers at various levels and facilitated the development of a novel chemical reaction for the synthesis of diverse bacterial carbohydrates, which are essential for understanding fundamental biological processes and advancing the development of next-generation medicines.


Last Modified: 11/21/2024
Modified by: Weiping Tang
